pull_request.title: Fix OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD logic for upstream imports
pull_request.body:
The first commit fixes the OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD logic for the schemes that are imported using copy_from_upstream. Previously you would only get functional runtime CPU feature detection if you compiled on a machine with every CPU feature.

The second commit fixes our interpretation of "required_flag: pclmulqdq" in META.yml. The presence of this flag should cause us to compile with "-mpclmul" not "-mpclmulqdq". Upstream will not change META.yml, see https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/pull/381#issuecomment-799186507.

The third commit is a mitigation for #946.

repo.name: liboqs

pull_request.title: Patch Kyber, Dilithium, and SPHINCS to use our SHA3
pull_request.body:
This PR patches Kyber, Dilithium, and SPHINCS to use our SHA3 .

The Kyber and Dilithium patches are bit more minimalistic than the ones that were originally part of #922. I've added shims for the "absorb_once" and "squeezebytes" functions.

Dilithium's fips202.c differs from Kyber's and PQClean's, so the patches here make some name changes like "shake128_absorb" to "shake128_inc_absorb". This prevents us from needing a parallel set of shims just for Dilithium.

The SPHINCS patches just remove unused files.

review.body: As you asked for comment, I find it inconvenient (unusual?) to only have the release notes for this (latest) release in this file and not all release notes (dated, under subtitles by release, i.e., an ever growing list) in the same file (see [e.g. here](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/CHANGES.md). This way, significant changes could be added by PR authors/reviewers to the file and a release would only necessitate adding a new heading. Readers in turn would be able to see progress over time in one place. But as a) all main changes since the last release have been captured now and b) it is done like this also in liboqs I don't want this to hold up the release.
